author_ssm: Jasmine Soliman for Akkasah: Center for Photography at NYUAD
unittitle_ssm: Bilder-Atlas zu Mekka and ephemera - Hisham Khatib Collection
abstract_ssm:
A partial Bilder-Atlas zu Mekka von Dr. C. Snouck Hurgronje. Herausgegeben von Het Koninklijk Instituut voor Taal-, Land- en Volkenkunde van Nederlandsch-Indië te 's-Gravenhage (Picture Atlas of Mekka by Dr. Christiaan Snouck Hurgronje. Published by the Royal Institute for Linguistics, Land and Ethnology of the Dutch East Indies in The Hague). Imprint Haag: Martinus Nijhoff, 1888.
The folio includes photographic and lithographic prints by Muḥammad Ṣādiq Bey (1822 or 1823–1902 or 1903), an Egyptian army engineer who took the first photographs of Medina in 1861 and Mecca in 1880-81 and by al-Sayyid ʻAbd al-Ghaffār (recognised as the first Meccan photographer). Digitized alongside the Bilder-Atlas was the accompanying ephemera including an article entitled How the Mecca pilgrimage is Conducted by A. E. Wort in The Wide World Magazine (1900) and from the March 1937 edition of Life Magazine, The Camera Overseas: Egypt Sends a Carpet to Mecca.

heading_ssm: Bilder-Atlas zu Mekka and ephemera - Hisham Khatib Collection

collection_ssm: Bilder-Atlas zu Mekka and ephemera - Hisham Khatib Collection
unittitle_ssm: Die Moschee und der nordwestliche Theil der Stadt. 1. Amt des Qâdhî's; 2. Festung auf dem Djèbèl Hindî; 3. Gebäude des Zemzembrunnens; 7. Mimbar (Kanzel); 8. Maqâm èl-Hanafî; 9. Maqâm èl-Mâlikî; 10. Maqâm èl-Hambalî. Die Treppen zur Ka'bah und der Maqâm Ibrâhîm (zugleich Maqâm ès-Schâfi'î) sind hier durch das Zemzemgebäude dem Auge entzogen. The mosque and the northwestern part of the city. The Office of the Qâdhî; 2. Fortress on the Djèbèl Hindî 3. Building of the Zemzem Fountain; 7. Mimbar (pulpit); 8. Maqâm èl-Hanafî; 9. Maqâm èl-Mâlikî; 10. Maqâm èl-Hambalî. The stairs to the Ka'bah and the Maqâm Ibrâhîm (at the same time Maqâm ès-Schâfi'î) are here hidden behind the Zemzem building.

unittitle_ssm: Mekkaner. Kaufleute (Mekka und Djiddah). Ali Rèjjis (aus einem Geschlechte von Obersten der Mu'èddin, welches von Abdallah ibn Zubair herstammen soll). Mu'èddin (Aufrufer zum Gottesdienste). Meccan. Merchants (Mecca and Jeddah). Ali Rjjjis (from a lineage of Colonel Mu'èddin, which is said to come from Abdallah ibn Zubair). Mu'èddin (caller to prayer).
